name: OpenBiome
headline: A nonprofit stool bank enabling access to fecal transplants.
description: We are a nonprofit stool bank, expanding safe access to fecal transplants and catalyzing research on the human microbiome.

founders.name: Majdi Osman
founders.description: Co-founder, OpenBiome. Physician scientist researching the role of the microbiome in human health.

founders.name: Carolyn Edelstein
founders.description: Carolyn Edelstein is OpenBiome’s Executive Director. She previously worked at Development Innovation Ventures, a program at USAID designed to fund ideas that could improve millions of lives in more cost-effective ways than standard international development approaches. Carolyn helped launch the Global Innovation Fund, a $200M multilateral development fund built on the DIV model, before co-founding OpenBiome.

##  Harnessing the Microbes Within Us to Improve Health for All
![openbiome_11_17_22_4166](https://openbiome.org/wp-content/uploads/bb-plugin/cache/openbiome_11_17_22_4166-800x534-circle.jpg)
We partner with leading researchers and innovators to close [critical gaps](http://openbiome.org/<https:/openbiome.org/filling-gaps-in-microbiome-health-research/>) in microbiome science and healthcare.
##  Our Impact
Over the past 10 years, we've pushed scientific boundaries and set gold standards
![A scientist in lab attire holding a stool sample bag](https://openbiome.org/wp-content/uploads/MaintainingSafeAccess-800x800.jpg)
![FMTtreatment_Hero](https://openbiome.org/wp-content/uploads/bb-plugin/cache/FMTtreatment_Hero-circle.jpg)
0+
Patients have received urgently needed investigational fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) treatments distributed by OpenBiome.
[ Learn About FMT ](http://openbiome.org/<https:/openbiome.org/fmt-treatment-parent/about-fmt-treatment/>)
![openbiome_11_17_22_3911](https://openbiome.org/wp-content/uploads/openbiome_11_17_22_3911.jpg)
![Mission_Icon1](https://openbiome.org/wp-content/uploads/bb-plugin/cache/Mission_Icon1-circle.jpg)
0+
Clinical trials and single patient case studies have used OpenBiome investigational FMT to explore the microbiome as a treatment target for a wide range of indications.
[ Access Our Research Catalog ](http://openbiome.org/<https:/store.openbiome.org/collections/all>)
##  Research Programs
Our programs accelerate microbiome science— ethically and equitably— to improve health worldwide.
[ ![OpenBiome's Microbiome Therapeutics Program develops new approaches for treating urgent health challenges from malnutrition to mental health](https://openbiome.org/wp-content/uploads/malnutrition.jpg) ](http://openbiome.org/<https:/openbiome.org/global-health/malnutrition/>)
[**Malnutrition Program**](http://openbiome.org/<https:/openbiome.org/global-health/malnutrition/>) OpenBiome and our collaborators are developing live biotherapeutic therapies to help treat nearly 200 million children worldwide affected by malnutrition.
##  Latest News 
[](http://openbiome.org/<https:/openbiome.org/fmt-access/placing-an-order/>)
## Empowering microbiome research in underrepresented countries
OpenBiome's Chief Medical Officer, Dr. Majdi Osman, co-organized an [international retreat accelerating microbiome research to improve the health of children.](http://openbiome.org/<https:/sangerinstitute.blog/2023/05/22/empowering-microbiome-research-in-underrepresented-countries/>)
![](https://openbiome.org/wp-content/uploads/GGPgvv6WoAA-3Zm.jpeg)
[](http://openbiome.org/<https:/openbiome.org/feature/a-message-from-our-ceo-julie-barrett-obrien/>)
## A Message from our CEO, Julie Barrett O'Brien
[ READ MESSAGE ](http://openbiome.org/<https:/openbiome.org/feature/a-message-from-our-ceo-julie-barrett-obrien/>)
[](http://openbiome.org/<https:/openbiome.org/fmt-distribution-through-december-31/>)

##  Our Partners
OpenBiome is proud to have partnered with government and philanthropic organizations around the world to advance patient care and microbiome research.

OpenBiome has appeared in national and international publications. Read more coverage [here](http://openbiome.org/<https:/openbiome.org/features/>).
[ ![](https://openbiome.org/wp-content/uploads/BBC-highlight-1-800x533.png) ](http://openbiome.org/<https:/www.bbc.com/future/article/20211115-how-your-microbiome-can-improve-your-health> "opens in a new window")

The investigational fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) treatments discussed on this website and associated OpenBiome materials have been not been approved or licensed by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration or by any other regulatory authority, and it is not commercially available in any market. OpenBiome is acting only in the capacity of distributor of investigational FMT preparations manufactured by the University of Minnesota under an FDA-reviewed investigational new drug application (IND).
![](http://openbiome.org/wp-content/uploads/openbiome-logo-footer.svg)
[Privacy](http://openbiome.org/</privacy-policy/>)

The investigational fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) treatments discussed on this website and associated OpenBiome materials have been not been approved or licensed by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration or by any other regulatory authority, and it is not commercially available in any market. OpenBiome is acting only in the capacity of distributor of investigational FMT preparations manufactured by the University of Minnesota under an FDA-reviewed investigational new drug application (IND).
![](http://openbiome.org/wp-content/uploads/openbiome-logo-footer.svg)

generated_description:
OpenBiome is a pioneering nonprofit organization established in 2013 and based in Cambridge, Massachusetts. With a mission centered around expanding safe access to fecal transplants, OpenBiome operates as a stool bank and plays a crucial role in catalyzing research focused on the human microbiome.

Having emerged from Y Combinator's Batch W20, OpenBiome is equipped with a dedicated team of approximately 70 employees. They aim to improve health outcomes by promoting the use of fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) to treat conditions such as Clostridium difficile infection and other microbiome-related diseases.

Their website, [openbiome.org](http://openbiome.org), offers a wealth of resources for both clinicians and patients, including updates on investigational FMT, access to research materials, and ongoing initiatives in global health. Currently, they are involved in various programs that not only distribute investigational FMT but also contribute to microbiome conservation and health research on a global scale.

One striking aspect of OpenBiome's work is its commitment to ethical practices in microbiome science and the notable impact they've achieved over the last decade. They've helped thousands of patients receive necessary FMT treatments and fostered clinical trials exploring the microbiome as a treatment avenue for numerous health issues.

Moreover, OpenBiome has partnered with significant organizations like the CDC and the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, underscoring their broad influence in health advancements. Their latest initiatives include a focus on combating malnutrition and exploring mental health through microbiome therapies—big challenges that require innovative biotherapeutic approaches.

In summary, OpenBiome is not just a stool bank; it’s a hub of microbiome knowledge and a critical player in the effort to harness our world of microbes for better health solutions. Their proactive approach to research, treatment, and ethical responsibility sets a benchmark in health innovation.
